1. A 2-year-old male child was brought to the pediatric clinic with complaints of silvery-gray hair and delayed developmental milestones since infancy. The parents also noted episodes of recurrent fever and lethargy over the past three months. Physical examination revealed hypopigmented skin, generalized hypotonia, and mild hepatosplenomegaly. Neurologic assessment showed signs of developmental regression and intermittent seizures. Laboratory tests demonstrated pancytopenia and elevated serum ferritin levels, raising suspicion for hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH). A hair shaft microscopy revealed large clumps of unevenly distributed melanin granules. Genetic testing confirmed mutations in the RAB27A gene, consistent with Griscelli Syndrome type 2. The child was started on immunosuppressive therapy in preparation for hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.
